questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding graft survival:

choices.text: Both CD4 and CD8 T cells play a role in graft rejection
Only CD8 T cells play a role in graft rejection
Only CD4 T cells play a role in graft rejection
Neither CD4 nor CD8 T cells play a role in graft rejection

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Both CD4 and CD8 T cells play a role in graft rejection:

  • The given image shows a Kaplan Meier survival graph.
  • On administrating both Anti-CD4 and Anti-CD8, the survival of the graft increases from 15 days to 60 days.
  • This signifies that both CD4 and CD8 T cells are involved in graft rejection. 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D- These statements are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: In a train accident, there were 74 dead, 64 were severely injured, 20 moderately injured and 12 mildly injured. Colour coding in triage, from highest to lowest priority is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D- Red-Yellow-Green-Black

Explanation:

Triage:

  • During a disaster, the quantity and severity of injuries overwhelm the operative capacity of the health facilities. Triage involves rapidly organizing the injured individuals based on the severity of their injuries and survival with prompt interventions.
  • During triage, tagging should be done to each individual, including:

    • Name

    • Age

    • Place of origin

    • Triage category

    • Diagnosis and

    • Initial treatment.

 

Color coding in triage:

Types of triage:

  • Reverse triage:

    • Used in surges (bed scarcity) and during wars.

    • Priority: Green → Yellow → Red.

  • Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment (START):

    • Done in remote or inaccessible areas.

    • Laymen can start doing triage before rescue teams reach.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of hepatocellular carcinoma in a factory worker employed in a groundnut factory who does not consume alcohol and has had a prolonged duration of employment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option D) Aflatoxins

Explanation:

Aflatoxicosis:

Clinical features
  • Features of hepatotoxicity (jaundice, hepatomegaly)
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma

Causative agent
  • Infestation of Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus over stored rice, wheat, and corn
  • Produce mycotoxins: aflatoxin B1 & G1 (both are hepatotoxic & carcinogenic)

Risk factors
  • Storage temperature of 11 to 37 degree Celsius
  • Moisture content >16%

Prevention
  • Educating people
  • Moisture content <10% during storage

Incorrect Options

Beta oxalyl amino alanine (Option A): Beta oxalyl amino alanine, also known as BMAA, is a neurotoxic amino acid that has been associated with the development of lathyrism, neurodegenerative diseases such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and Parkinson's disease. It is not directly linked to hepatocellular carcinoma.

Smoke from factory (Option B): While exposure to certain industrial pollutants and chemicals can contribute to the development of various cancers, including liver cancer, the given scenario specifically mentions the worker being non-alcoholic and working in a groundnut factory. Therefore, smoke from the factory is not the most probable cause in this case.

Sanguinarine (Option C): It is a toxic alkaloid present in argemone oil. It causes epidemic dropsy. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of jaundice in this newborn presenting with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, intrahepatic cholestasis, high alkaline phosphatase, and the presence of eosinophilic, PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules in liver biopsy specimens, suggestive of Alpha 1 AT deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Neonatal hepatitis

Explanation:

Neonatal hepatitis:

Neonatal hepatitis is inflammation of the liver that occurs in newborn infants. It can be caused by various factors, including viral infections (such as hepatitis viruses), metabolic disorders, genetic conditions, and drug-induced liver injury.

In the given scenario, the presentation indicative of neonatal hepatitis includes:

  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia
  • Intrahepatic cholestasis
  • High alkaline phosphatase,
  • Presence of eosinophilic PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules on liver biopsy

Hypoplasia of biliary tract (Option A): Hypoplasia of the biliary tract refers to underdevelopment or incomplete formation of the bile ducts. It presents with pale stools and bile duct proliferation on biopsy, and can lead to impaired bile flow and subsequent cholestasis. However, it is not the most common cause of jaundice in the neonates.

Choledochal cyst (Option C) : A choledochal cyst is a congenital anomaly characterized by dilatation of the bile ducts. It can cause bile flow obstruction and subsequently leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, jaundice and an abdominal mass due to bile duct dilation. Unlike A1AT deficiency, it shows extrahepatic obstruction on imaging and lacks PAS-positive inclusions.

Physiological (Option D): Physiological jaundice, is a normal and temporary condition that occurs in many newborns due to the immature liver's ability to process bilirubin efficiently. It presents with unconjugated bilirubinemia, not conjugated.

questions.text: In a triage system, the patients with the highest priority and those who are deceased are identified by color coding.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) Red and black

Explanation: Triage:

During a disaster, the quantity and severity of injuries overwhelm the operative capacity of the health facilities. Triage involves rapidly organizing the injured individuals based on the severity of their injuries and survival with prompt interventions.

During triage, tagging should be done to each individual, including:

  1. Name
  2. Age
  3. Place of origin
  4. Triage category
  5. Diagnosis and
  6. Initial treatment.

Color coding in triage:

Types of triage:

  • Reverse triage:
    • Used in surges (bed scarcity) and during wars.
    • Priority: Green→Yellow→Red.
  • Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment (START):
    • Done in remote or inaccessible areas.
    • Laymen can start doing triage before rescue teams reach.

questions.text: In a boarding school where students share the same canteen, one student experienced abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. Subsequently, other students began showing similar symptoms. Which investigations should the local medical officer consider in order to arrive at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) IgM for hepatitis A

Explanation: Hepatitis A is transmitted by the faecal-oral route. Hence the students can be suspected of acquiring Hepatitis A from the contaminated food. The diagnostic tests for Hepatitis A are a Stool sample, and an Anti HAV IgM antibody performed after 2 weeks of increase in the liver enzyme.

Hepatitis A Virus (HAV)

  • Most Common Cause of viral hepatitis in Children
  • Most Common Cause of Acute Relapsing viral hepatitis

Virus characteristics:

  • HAV is a 27-nm, nonenveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus, resistant to heat, acid, and ether.

Mode of Transmission: Fecal-oral route.

Incubation period: ~3–4 weeks.

Pathogenesis:

  • Replication is limited to the liver but found in the liver, bile, stools, and blood during the late incubation and pre-icteric phases.
  • Faecal shedding, viremia, and infectivity decrease rapidly once jaundice appears.

Clinical presentation:

  • Asymptomatic cases
  • Jaundice
  • Cholestatic hepatitis
  • Fulminant hepatitis - Acute liver failure especially in older adults or those with preexisting liver conditions.
  • Does not lead to chronic liver disease.

Diagnosis:

  • Acute illness - anti-HAV IgM antibodies. (Option B)
  • HAV RNA can persist in stools, liver, and serum for months after acute illness but is not correlated with persistent infectivity.
  • Previous infection: IgG anti-HAV
  • LFT: Elevated bilirubin, serum aminotransferases, and alkaline phosphatase (ALP).

Treatment:

  • Most cases are self-limiting
  • No specific antiviral treatment
  • Symptomatic management (10 % Dextrose)

Prevention:

  • Inactivated vaccination: Single antigen or in combination with hepatitis B
  • Good sanitary conditions and measures

IgA for hepatitis A (Option A): IgA is not specific to Hepatitis A and does not give accurate results.

IgM for hepatitis B (Option C) and IgG for hepatitis B (Option D): Hepatitis A is transmitted by the faecal-oral route. Whereas hepatitis B is transmitted through blood or body fluids.

questions.text: What type of learning is demonstrated when a doctor instructs an intern on proper technique for performing the knee reflex, emphasizing its significance in clinical practice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Psychomotor learning

Explanation:

  • Psychomotor learning refers to the acquisition of motor skills or physical movements through practice and repetition. In this scenario, the doctor is teaching the intern how to perform the knee reflex test, which involves a physical examination technique. The intern is expected to learn and develop the necessary motor skills to perform the knee reflex accurately.

 

Cognitive learning (Option A): Cognitive learning refers to the acquisition of knowledge, understanding, or mental skills.

Affective learning (Option C): Affective learning pertains to the acquisition of attitudes, values, or emotional responses.

Repeated learning (Option D): Repeated learning is a generic term that doesn't specify the type of learning involved.

Correct answer: Option D) Lepromatous leprosy

Explanation:

  • The given image is Lepromatous Leprosy. It is one of the types of Leprosy and is characterized by widespread, poorly defined, shiny-surfaced, hypopigmented, and erythematous macules with normal sensation.
  • Typical leonine features include a thickened forehead, lost brow hairs, and eyelashes (madarosis), a distorted nose, and thickened earlobes.

Transmission of Mycobacterium leprae

  • Source of Infection:
    • Leprosy is solely a human disease.
    • Infected individuals are the only source.
  • Transmission Route:
    • The precise route is unclear.
    • Significant shedding of bacilli through nasal secretions.
    • Possible transmission through the respiratory tract or skin.

Classification of Leprosy

Madrid Classification:

Type

Characteristics

Lepromatous Leprosy

Low host resistance, abundant bacilli in lesions, widespread lesions, higher transmission likelihood (Option D).

Tuberculoid Leprosy

High resistance, limited well-defined skin lesions, minimal bacilli in the lesions (Option A ruled out).

Dimorphous (Borderline)

Characteristics of both lepromatous and tuberculoid forms, potential to shift between the two (Option C ruled out).

Indeterminate Leprosy

Early, unstable stage, may resolve spontaneously or progress to other forms.

 

Leishmaniasis (Option B): The clinical features seen in the image given is not indicative of leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Installation and usage of sanitary latrines by general public constitutes which level of prevention:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Health promotion

Explanation:

  • Health promotion encourages healthy behaviors and environments. Installing sanitary latrines promotes hygiene and prevents diseases.

Primary prevention includes:

  • Health promotion: (Option A)
    • Health education camps on exercise and lifestyle diseases.
    • Mental health promotion and counselling in schools and colleges.
    • Implementing strict laws against drinking and driving to prevent road traffic accidents due to impaired driving
  • Specific protection: (Option B ruled out)
    • Administration of MR vaccination to children prevents measles and rubella infection via active immunisation, as the risk of infection is high during childhood
    • Iodisation of salt helps prevent endemic goitre, especially in the Himalayan region, as they lack iodine in their diet

 

 

Level of Prevention

Goals

Examples

Primordial

To prevent the establishment of risk factors

  • Lifestyle modification
  • Health promotion

Primary

Interventions to prevent the onset of disease
  • Vaccinations
  • Health education
  • Family planning
  • Use of mosquito nets
  • Pre-placement examinatio

Secondary

Early detection and prompt treatment of disease to prevent complications (Option C ruled out)
  • Screening tests (e.g., mammograms, PAP smears)
  • Self-examinations
  • Health camps with screening DOTS for TB; ART for HIV; MDT for leprosy.

Tertiary

Interventions to manage and reduce complications of existing disease to prevent disability or death (Option D ruled out)
  • Rehabilitation
  • Physical therapy
  • Chronic disease management programs
  • Reconstructive surgery
